Religion effects it positively.  This is the core of the utilitarian argument for faith and Christianity. And a review of 498 studies published in peer-reviewed journals concluded that a large majority of them showed a positive correlation between religious commitment and higher levels of perceived well-being and self-esteem and lower levels of hypertension, depression, and clinical delinquency.  A meta-analysis of 34 recent studies published between 1990 and 2001 found that religiosity has a salutary relationship with psychological adjustment, being related to less psychological distress, more life satisfaction, and better self-actualization.  Finally, a recent systematic review of 850 research papers on the topic concluded that "the majority of well-conducted studies found that higher levels of religious involvement are positively associated with indicators of psychological well-being (life satisfaction, happiness, positive affect, and higher morale) and with less depression, suicidal thoughts and behaviour, drug/alcohol use/abuse." Source: Happiness

Hard to say, honestly. The correlation between religion and mental health varies significantly by religion, as well as by region and culture. There are enough factors that go into mental health statistics that it’s frequently hard to pick out what effect religion has. For example, traditionally, being highly religious has meant being part of an organized, robust and involved community, leading to more social activity, public engagement, and both practical and personal support, which are all things that correlate highly with good mental health. On the other hand, if someone is so religiously extreme that they cut off contact with most people around them (for fear of being corrupted) and become isolated, that’s bad for mental health. Note that all of this is true long before you take any consideration of the personal and spiritual implications of belief, or your adherence to the principles of any religion, let alone any question of whether or not the religion is true. Reality is, humans are complex, mental health is complex, and figuring out what factors impact it is actually a really tough statistical puzzle, most of the time.

Is religion detrimental to mental health? Seems unlikely. Born-again, committed Christians, who worship regularly, enjoy better mental health than average, including less depression, stress and suicidal thoughts. They also enjoy happier and longer-lasting marriages and even better sex than average! This is not surprising. The Christian gospel includes: - forgiveness of sin - letting go of resentments and unhealthy ambitions - a sense of purpose - valuing things that are more important than money and status - developing beneficial traits such as kindness and compassion - building community (both in church and outward social efforts) All of these things benefit mental health. The flip side is that atheism can increase depression, as one believes that there is no purpose to life and that everything is meaningless, whilst cultivating tendencies that lead to increased alienation and isolation (support for divorce, reduced community spirit, lower barriers to infidelity, etc.).
